docs.lead_paragraph: Many New Yorkers, already facing increases in health premiums of more than 10 percent, could face even greater increases after a ruling by state insurance regulators. The ruling applies to a popular form of coverage: point-of-service plans, which allow customers to get care outside their health maintenance organization's network if they pay extra. Under the ruling, insurance companies can no longer offer lower rates for such plans to large companies based on the low health care spending of their employees.
docs.abstract: Many New Yorkers already facing increases in health premiums of more than 10 percent, could face even greater increases in wake of ruling by state insurance regulators on point-of-service plans, which allow customers to get care outside their health service network if they pay extra; ruling bars insurance companies from offering lower rates for such plans to large companies based on low health care spending of employees; regulators say some insurers were overstating percentage of out-of-network coverage, giving themselves more flexibility in pricing and subsequently offering more attractive deals to big companies with generally healthy employees in order to get business; say smaller companies and groups, or those with less healthy employees, ended up paying more; independent insurance agents say ruling could force up monthly cost for some plans by $100 to $200 per family for companies that provide family coverage; monthly premiums for such coverage currently average $650, with employers' share varying widely (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton and Republican leaders warily met today to discuss a broad array of tax and spending proposals that expose the deep divisions and distrust between the parties. With Mr. Clinton back from a weeklong tour of impoverished areas and Congress returning to work after the Fourth of July recess, talks began in earnest in the Oval Office late this afternoon on matters of social policy and money that will drive negotiations in Washington through the fall budget-writing season, and probably well into the 2000 campaign.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Republican leaders warily meet in Oval Office to discuss broad array of tax and spending proposals that expose deep divisions and distrust between parties; Clinton reportedly tells Republican leaders he is willing to work with them to use bulk of projected budget surpluses of $2.9 trillion over next 10 years to insure solvency of Social Security and Medicare; reportedly repeated view that Republican plans to cut taxes by $800 billion or more over next decade would make it impossible to revamp Medicare or to add billions in spending on new programs; reportedly expressed willingness to discuss tax cuts of smaller magnitude, but after dealing with what he views as more pressing priorities; White House meeting also attended by Democratic leaders (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton and Republican leaders warily met today to discuss a broad array of tax and spending proposals that expose the deep divisions and distrust between the parties.    With Mr. Clinton back from a weeklong tour of impoverished areas and...

docs.lead_paragraph: After a year of stalling by the Republicans, the Senate began debate yesterday on how to curb unfair health insurance practices. There is widespread public concern that the shift to managed care has left consumers defenseless when they are improperly denied needed care by their health plans. That is the rationale for Federal action. Knowing that voters care about this issue, Republican leaders are offering a bill that, they hope, will give them political cover at election time. But the bill is weak, and will do little to deter wrongful actions by health plans. The Democrats will try as best they can to strengthen it with amendments aimed at closing loopholes.
docs.abstract: Editorial, commenting on start of Senate debate on patients' Bill of Rights, says pending legislation is weak and will do little to deter wrongful actions by health plans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After all the indictments and revelations of scandal, the new leaders of District Council 37, New York City's giant municipal union, have taken steps to reshape the union as the muscular force it once was. But in trying to prepare for a more forceful role in coming contract negotiations and next year's Senate race, District Council 37 has clashed repeatedly with the Giuliani administration, which has attacked the union's new combativeness as a misguided effort that serves neither its members nor the public.

headline.main: Vowing to Go From Scandal to Strength, City Union Looks for a Fight

docs.abstract: New leaders of District Council 37, after all indictments and revelations of scandal, have taken steps to reshape union as force it once was; have clashed with Giuliani administration, which has attacked union's combativeness; District Council 37, under trustee Lee Saunders, has opposed Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani on workfare and privatization; says it will not accept two-year wage freeze as it did in its current contract; Manhattan Dist Atty Robert M Morgenthau plans to empanel grand jury after Labor Day to hear new evidence about wrongdoing by council officials; Saunders photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The first comprehensive study of the rapidly growing number of emotionally disturbed people in the nation's jails and prisons has found that there are 283,800 inmates with mental illness, about 16 percent of the jail population. The report confirms the belief of many state, local and Federal experts that jails and prisons have become the nation's new mental hospitals. The study, released by the Justice Department yesterday, paints a grim statistical portrait, detailing how mentally ill inmates tend to follow a revolving door from homelessness to incarceration and then back to the streets with little treatment, many of them arrested for crimes that grow out of their illnesses.

headline.main: Prisons Brim With Mentally Ill, Study Finds

docs.abstract: First comprehensive study of rapidly growing number of emotionally disturbed people in nation's jails and prisons finds there are 283,800 inmates with mental illness, or about 16 percent of jail population; study, released by Justice Department, confirms belief of many state, local and Federal experts that jails and prisons have become nation's new mental hospitals; paints grim statistical portrait of how inmates tend to follow revolving door from homelessness to incarceration and back to streets with little treatment, many arrested for crimes that grow out their illnesses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 A Plan Is Reached For Kashmir Withdrawal India and Pakistan said that rival forces battling for the past two months over the Indian state of Kashmir would begin a phased withdrawal, heralding an end to the latest confrontation between the world's newest nuclear powers. A1 Step Toward Mideast Peace Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Ehud Barak, the new Prime Minister of Israel, said that a new era of peacemaking lay ahead at the first Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting in seven months. docs.lead_paragraph: When the Senate takes up legislation on Monday to define patients' rights, Democrats will argue that hundreds of people have been injured or even died because they were denied necessary care by cost-conscious health maintenance organizations. So it is rather surprising to find that the chief lobbyist for the managed care industry is herself a Democrat, a veteran of the trade union movement and a longtime advocate of universal health insurance.

headline.main: Unlikely Lobbyist Will Lead H.M.O.'s Into Battle

docs.abstract: Interview with Karen M Ignagni, chief lobbyist for managed care industry who will lead industry into battle as Senate holds four days of impassioned debate on proposals to set comprehensive Federal standards for health insurance plans; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After nearly two decades in which their desire for big tax cuts was overwhelmed by efforts to eliminate the Federal budget deficit, Republicans in Congress will begin a concerted push in the coming week to pass the largest and most broadly distributed tax reduction since 1981. They will have to overcome opposition from President Clinton and most Democrats in Congress, as well as indifference among voters, who consistently rank tax cuts below issues like improving education and shoring up Social Security when asked about their priorities.

headline.main: G.O.P. RENEWS PUSH FOR A BIG TAX CUT, CITING THE SURPLUS

docs.abstract: Republicans in Congress are set to begin concerted push to pass largest and most broadly distributed tax reduction since 1981; will have to overcome opposition from Pres Clinton and most Democrats, as well as indifference among voters; Rep Bill Archer, chief Republican tax writer in House, says centerpiece of his bill will be reduction of 10 percent in all personal income tax rates, measure Democrats thought they had headed off; change, which would be phased in gradually over 10 years, would cost $400 billion in that period, half $864 billion in tax cuts that Archer intends to include in his bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's oldest civil rights organization returned yesterday to New York, the city of its founding, to celebrate its 90th birthday and confront issues as topical as racial profiling by the police and getting more blacks to use the Internet. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opened its six-day annual convention at the New York Hilton and Towers in midtown Manhattan by listing several other concerns at the top of its agenda -- like school vouchers, integration, voter registration and health care -- and preparing for three high-profile political appearances.
docs.abstract: NAACP opens annual convention in New York City, where it will focus on police profiling and getting more blacks to use the Internet; other concerns on the agenda are school vouchers, integration, voter registration and health care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sheri Jayne Caplan and Dr. Kenneth Alan Merkatz are to be married this evening at the Pierre in Manhattan. Rabbi Lawrence A. Hoffman is to officiate. Until last month, the bride, 33, was a vice president and an assistant general counsel at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Manhattan investment bank. She graduated from Yale University and received a law degree from the University of Virginia. She is a daughter of Helen and Harry B. Caplan of Boynton Beach, Fla. Her father retired as an independent insurance broker in Boston. Her mother, also retired, taught the sixth grade at Andover West Middle School in Andover, Mass.
